user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_empty:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_empty (enum MHD_ResponseFlags flags)
{
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  r = (struct MHD_Response *) MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_Response));
  if (NULL != r)
  {
    if (MHD_mutex_init_ (&r->mutex))
    {
      r->fd = -1;
      r->reference_count = 1;
      /* If any flags combination will be not allowed, replace the next
       * assignment with MHD_set_response_options() call. */
      r->flags = flags;

      return r; /* Successful result */
    }
    free (r);
  }
  return NULL; /* Something failed */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (MHD_mutex_init_ (&r->mutex))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: &r->mutex is passed to MHD_mutex_init_ to initialize/modify the mutex, so the pointer must refer to a mutable (non-const) object. Rule 8.13 does not require const qualification here. A violation would occur only if the function were declared to accept a pointer-to-const while it actually modifies the mutex.
